lower compared to expectations for a wet year. The pastoral households consumed an average of 2.4 litres per day compared to 3.7 litres in agro-pastoral livelihood zones. The variation was attributed to significant production in agro pastoral areas compared to pastoral areas which have also experience more flooding

especially in Magadi, Keekonyokia, Figure 12: Household milk consumption; Kajiado County, April 2024 Loodokilani, Lenkism, Amboseli, and

Ewuaso. The ongoing flooding is expected to affect milk production and consumption, but there

is a possibility of recovery once the floodwaters recede.

5.2

Food Consumption Score

The season's food consumption trend has improved, which indicates an increase in

the variety and frequency food groups. By April

of different 2024, the

proportion of pastoral households that fell under borderline food consumption

scores reduced to 6.8 percent from 8.8 percent in March while agro-pastoral

areas improved to acceptable food consumption scores (Figure 13). The

Figure 13: Food consumption; Kajiado County, Feb-Apr improvements were attributed to improved livestock productivity resulting in an improvement of the household purchasing power and access to food. Increased access to milk and favourable terms of trade are helping to mitigate the effects of flooding due to the ongoing enhanced rainfall.

Page 10 of 15
---
5.3 5.3.1

Health And Nutrition Status Nutrition Status of Children Aged 6-59 Months As household food availability and access

improve, the proportion of children under five years at risk of malnutrition has gradually decreased, reaching 7.1% in April (Figure 14). The factors that contributed to this trend were stable milk consumption, access to cereals, and a rise in households' purchasing power due to improved livestock productivity. The

five-year average for this time of year is

Figure 14: % of U5 at risk of malnutrition; Kajiado 8.0%. Malnutrition among children is a County, April 2024 major concern in pastoral and flooded areas of Ngurumani, Shompole, Magadi, Pakase, Kamukuru, Lenkism, Losinyai, Nkama, Leremis, Kijiji, Kware, Mithika, Gataka, Enkoirorei, Maparasha, Emotoroki, and Noonkujet.

5.3.2 Health There were no reported cases of human disease outbreaks in April. However, in Dalalekutuk, Ewuaso Kidong, Mbirikani, and Oldonyonyokie, 77% of the under-five children monitored across the county who were sick had fever with chills like malaria, while 23 percent had diarrhea. The contamination of drinking water sources caused by floods is likely to lead to the increase of waterborne diseases like cholera, typhoid, and diarrhoea. Disruptions in health services are likely due to floods submerging health facilities or destruction of access roads leading to such facilities. In flood-prone areas, mental health issues may arise from displacement and destruction of property.

5.4 Coping Strategies Index Since January this year, there has been a gradual decline in the average coping strategy index, which indicates that households are less stressed when getting food or money to buy it. The

average coping strategy index in April was 5.7, which was 7 and 13 percent lower than the previous month and the five-year average, respectively (Figure 15). The improvement was attributed to availability of cereals at household level following good harvest, improved

Page 11 of 15
---
purchasing power and the above-average long rains driving increased agricultural

wage labor opportunities and incomes. The primary way households coped was

Figure 1: Coping strategy index; Kajiado, April 2024

by eating less preferred food. Floods and flash floods have led to the destruction of

properties, loss of lives, displacement of people, and disruption of market access

which may constrain household food access, forcing households to apply

livelihood and consumption-based coping strategies in the coming months.

6.0 FOOD SECURITY PROGNOSIS Increased rainfall in the county led to better agricultural production, and wages which will

increase access to food, water, and pasture, lower food commodity prices, and improve nutrition. Due to the above-average rainfall, particularly in April, the county experienced destructive

flooding in several areas. River bursts and excessive rains led to floods and flash floods, which resulted in at least 100 sheep/goats drowning, over 187 hectares of farmland damaged, several

households affected, with over 2,000 displaced. Structural damage including roads such as Mile 46-Singiraine-Kamukuru, Kajiado-Mile 46, Elangata Wuas -Kilonito, Mashenani-Eselenkei,

Athi River-Namanga and Oltepesi-Magadi temporarily closed by KeNHA, Oloyiankalani- Tikoishi, Noormirran-Suswa, Ewuaso-Najile. Bridges included Oloyiankalani-Tikoishi, Rongai-

Kiserian. Hospital/School included Entasopia hospital and Eroreti pry school. Markets submerged in water included Kamukuru, Torosei, Shompole and ACK Entasopia church.

As suppliers find new market routes, staple food prices are expected to rise while displacement, loss of household assets, and damage to key infrastructure, are likely to lead to mental health

issues due to stress. Standing waters have the potential to destroy some pasture species, contaminate or led to poisonous plants. The recovery process can be impeded by the heavy

settling of silt, sand, or gravel deposits on fields and the loss of topsoil. The prolonged humidity favours the survival of bacteria and viruses and fosters the spread of pests and diseases, posing

threats to livestock. The heavy rains have submerged various crop farms in water, caused soil erosion and nutrient leaching and a likely increase in crops pests and diseases which could affect

Page 12 of 15
---
the average yield for the long rain season leading to cascading impacts on food prices. Possible contamination of drinking water sources caused by floods is likely to lead to the increase of waterborne diseases like cholera, typhoid, and diarrhoea. Disruptions in health services are likely due to floods submerging health facilities or destruction of access roads leading to such facilities. Thus, the stability of food security situation in the county is not certain even with the good season’s performance. Humanitarian assistance, flood sensitization and structural repairs are urgently required.

8.0 RECOMMENDED IMMEDIATE RESPONSE OPTIONS • Risk assessments, including flood risk assessments, rescue operation, evacuation drills and simulations, and humanitarian assistance: By County Government, National Government, Red Cross, and Partners. • Tree planting campaign across the county: By County Government, National Government, Red Cross, and Partners. • Inspect critical infrastructures and monitor water levels in reservoirs to ensure preparedness: By County Government, National Government, Red Cross, and Partners. • Sensitization and capacity building of farmers on pasture harvesting and conservation; By County Department of Livestock Production and Partners.
